description: From Latin tūtēlārius (“guardian”), from tūtēla (“tutelage, guardianship; dependent, client”) + -ārius (“suffix denoting an agent of use”); analysable as tutelar +‎ -ary.

adjectives.description: tutelary (comparative more tutelary, superlative most tutelary)

examples: When a minor is involved, tutelary powers frequently accompany powers of attorney.

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to a guardian.
examples: My uncle is always happy to discharge his tutelary responsibilities towards me.

entries.meaning: Having the qualities of a tutor.
(religion, chiefly paganism) A deity or spirit serving as a guardian or protector of a place, person, culture, etc.; a tutelar, a tutelary deity.
examples: A tutelary is not a special sort of spirit or shrine; the word refers either to a clan shrine, which is theoretically the same for all members, or to the specific shrine or ancestor indicated by a diviner as being a man's own guardian spirit. Each individual has such a tutelary, but will not be aware of its name unless a diviner has been consulted.
